page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:   +
{{Expand Arabic|Ø§ÙØªØ³ÙØ³Ù Ø§ÙØ²ÙÙÙ ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ± (ÙØ§Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø±Ø­ÙÙ ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù)|date=March 2011}}
  +
{{Politics of Egypt}}
  +   +
The following is a chronological summary of the major events that took place during the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] after Mubarak's resignation as the [[List of Presidents of Egypt|fourth]] [[President of Egypt]].
  +   +
=== 12 February ===
  +
[[File:People celebrating the fall of Mubarak.ogg|thumb|People celebrating on the streets of Cairo]]
  +
[[File:Clean-up in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|Volunteers use shovels to dispose rubble, debris, and trash.]]
  +
A group of activists issued what they called the "People's CommuniquÃ© No 1", imitating the titles of communiquÃ©s from the Army. It demanded the dissolution of the cabinet Mubarak had appointed on 29 January; the suspension of the parliament elected in late 2010 in a poll widely suspected of rigging; the creation of a transitional five-member presidential council made up of four civilians and one military person; the formation of a transitional government to prepare for an election to take place within nine months, and of a body to draft a new democratic constitution; freedom for the media and syndicates, which represent groups such as lawyers, doctors and engineers, and for the formation of political parties; and the scrapping of military and emergency courts. They announced the formation of a council to call and call off mass protests.<ref name="reuterscomm1">[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/us-egypt-protesters-idUSTRE71B17Q20110212 Egypt protest leaders vow to protect revolution]. Reuters. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011</ref><ref name="darnetcom1">[http://distributedresearch.net/blog/2011/02/13/army-protesters-egypt-democracy-communique-no-1-demands Egypt: Protesters Communique No 1 Demands to The Army]. Andy Roberts DARnet. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref> The hours of [[curfew]] were reduced to between [[midnight]] and 6:00 Cairo local time.<ref name="aljazeera5">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/11/live-blog-feb-12-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
  +
The Egypt Supreme Council of the Armed Forces issued a ''communiquÃ©'' (CommuniquÃ© no. 4) in which they "promised to hand power to an elected, civilian government....[and] also pledged that Egypt would remain committed to all international treaties." <ref name="aljazeera5"/> [[Minister of Information]], [[Anas El-Fekky]] has been placed under [[house arrest]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Batty |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/feb/12/egypt-day-after-mubarak-quits |title=Egypt the day after Mubarak quits - live | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> He later resigned from his position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/12/live-blog-feb-13-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 13 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
Egypt's stock market regulator said the trading which was due to have started 13 February was delayed until 16 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LB984O3.html |title=Reopening of Egypt Exchange put off by 3 more days |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
In a gesture of new beginning, thousands of people began cleaning up Cairo's central Tahrir Square, which had been trashed by 18 days of rallies by hundreds of thousands of protesters and sporadic street battles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBHFH00.html |title=Protesters press for voice in Egyptian democracy' |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 13 February ===
  +
The army stated that the Constitution was suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egynews.net/wps/portal/news?params=115636 |title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©: ØªØ¹Ø·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙ Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± ÙØ­Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ù Ø§ÙØ´Ø¹Ø¨ ÙØ§ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù}}</ref><ref name="Leyne1">{{cite web|author=Jon Leyne |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12443678 |title=BBC News - Egyptian military dissolves parliament |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref><ref name="Deeb1">{{cite web|author=Sarah el Deeb|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBUL700.html |title=Egypt's military rulers dissolve parliament |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> Parliament was dissolved and the military announced it would stay in power six months until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential]] and [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary elections]] could be held.<ref name=Leyne1/> The High Council of Egyptian Armed Forces had selected its chief to represent the council. The caretaker Cabinet appointed by Mubarak will remain until a new Cabinet is formed after elections.<ref name=Deeb1/>
  +   +
After an inventory was completed it was determined that a total of 18 artifacts from the Egyptian Museum are missing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBRGK80.html |title=18 items missing from Egyptian Museum after unrest |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> About 70 objects were damaged.
  +   +
It was reported that secretary-general of the [[Arab League]] [[Amr Moussa]] was to stand down and run in the upcoming elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/02/11/feel_the_moussa_mentum |title=Feel the Moussa-mentum? | FP Passport |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 14 February ===
  +
Eight representatives from the demonstrators, including [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
  +   +
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html |title=Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 15 February ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
  +
[[Tarek El-Bishry]], a retired judge known for his pro-opposition views and for his support for a strong independent judiciary, was tasked with setting up the [[Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011|committee to reform the constitution]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121563130198336.html |title=Ex-judge to head Egypt reform panel - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> The changes would be formally announced within ten days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12466893 |title=BBC News - Egypt crisis: Army sets constitution reform deadline |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  +
Adly Fayed, the director of public security at the interior ministry, and Ismail El Shaer, Cairo's security chief, have been fired over their decision to open fire on the demonstrators.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
  +   +
[[Amr Moussa]] announced on 15 February that he would run in the presidential election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7288055.html |title=Arab League's Amr Moussa to run for Egypt's president - People's Daily Online |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced on the same day that it would form [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|a party]] to run in the parliamentary elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4028941,00.html |title=Egypt: Muslim Brotherhood plans political party - Israel News, Ynetnews |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date=1995-06-20 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 17 February ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
  +
The army stated on 17 February 2011 it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] and former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], as well as steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News - Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 18 February â Friday of Victory ===
  +
{{incomplete|section|date=February 2011}}
  +
On 18 February, influential Muslim cleric [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]], who arrived in Egypt after decades of exile in [[Qatar]], led the "Victory Day" Friday sermon in Tahrir Square attended by hundreds of thousands of people, while men who appeared Qaradawi's guards barred [[Wael Ghonim]] from joining him on stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Egypt-protest-hero-Wael-Ghonim-barred-from-stage/Article1-663996.aspx |title=Egypt protest hero Wael Ghonim barred from stage |publisher=Hindustan Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0218/Egypt-revolution-unfinished-Qaradawi-tells-Tahrir-masses |title=Egypt revolution unfinished, Qaradawi tells Tahrir masses |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/1832138.html |title=Mass protests as Egyptians mark "Victory Day" | Arabic region | Trend |publisher=En.trend.az |date= |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> On that same day, Wael Ghonim wrote the following on his [[Twitter]]: "I loved Sheikh Qaradawi Khutbah today. Was truly inspired when he said: Today I'm going to address both Muslims and Christians. Respect!"<ref>http://twitter.com/ghonim</ref>
  +   +
=== 20 February ===
  +   +
On 20 February, the constitutional reform committee announced its work was almost done,<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7293319.html</ref> and it was announced that the caretaker government would soon be reshuffled.<ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7293328.html</ref>
  +   +
=== 21 February ===
  +   +
On 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]], became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt - The Guardian |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref>
  +   +
=== 22 February ===
  +   +
A government reshuffle took place on 22 February. The key ministries of defense, interior, foreign, finance and justice remained unchanged, however. New ministers included [[Yehia el-Gamal]] as deputy prime minister, the [[New Wafd Party]]'s [[Monir Fakhri Abdel Nour]] as tourism minister and the [[Tagammu Party]]'s [[Gowdat Abdel-Khaleq]] as minister of social solidarity and social justice, as well as [[Ismail Ibrahim Fahmy]] as the new labor minister. The changes were not well-received by the public, as most of Mubarak's former supporters remained in the cabinet, and there were renewed calls for a demonstration to demand the resignation of the interim government.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/egypt-swears-in-new-cabinet-retains-mubarak-era-ministers-1.345069</ref>
  +   +
=== 25 February ===
  +
Protesters were set to return to Tahrir Square to continue to keep up the pressure on the interim government.<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE70O18Y20110225</ref>
  +   +
